Introduction

Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is a supraventricular tachycardia that likely occurs due to atrial conduction abnormalities triggered by acute illness.  It is most commonly seen in elderly patients with acute lung disease or an exacerbation of chronic lung disease.  The arrhythmia itself rarely causes symptoms (other than palpitations) or hemodynamic instability, but it is important to recognize and differentiate it from other supraventricular arrhythmias.

Pathophysiology



MAT likely develops due to atrial conduction abnormalities triggered by disturbances such as right atrial enlargement, catecholamine surge (eg, sepsis), and/or electrolyte imbalance (eg, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia).  The strong association with lung disease is likely largely driven by hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction leading to right atrial dilation and stretching.  Similar to atrial fibrillation, atrial remodeling (ie, conduction system, structural changes) driven by aging and comorbidities may create a substrate that makes it easier for MAT to develop.  Electrolyte abnormalities, which are common with acute illness, as well as the catecholamine surge that accompanies acute illness, likely further contribute to MAT development.

Risk factors



  • Advanced age:  MAT is usually seen in elderly patients, with average age 70 in those affected.
  • Underlying chronic lung disease:  Acute COPD exacerbation is the most common trigger of MAT.  Underlying chronic lung disease likely creates a substrate that makes it easier for MAT to develop.  Acute exacerbation of the disease then provides a trigger for the arrhythmia.
  • Acute lung disease:  MAT is also commonly seen with pneumonia and acute pulmonary embolism, sometimes in the absence of underlying chronic lung disease.
  • Other acute illnesses:  MAT is also sometimes seen with sepsis (with or without lung involvement) or exacerbation of acute heart failure.

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of MAT is driven primarily by the underlying disease process, and symptoms are also due to the underlying disease process (eg, cough, shortness of breath).  The arrhythmia itself is usually asymptomatic, other than palpitations in some cases.

Physical examination



Lung auscultation commonly shows signs of COPD exacerbation (eg, wheezing, poor air movement) or other underlying illness (eg, crackles and increased breath sounds in pneumonia).  Palpation of the radial pulse demonstrates an irregular rhythm with a rapid rate.

).  Because of the variability in atrial activity, the PR interval and the P-P interval (time between atrial contractions) are also variable.  The irregular atrial activity creates irregular ventricular activity (irregular R-R intervals).

Chest x-ray



Chest x-ray often reveals evidence of underlying lung disease or an exacerbation of lung disease (eg, hyperinflated lungs, airtrapping)

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of MAT should be suspected based on clinical presentation and is confirmed with ECG.  MAT is commonly recognized on continuous telemetry monitoring in patients hospitalized with acute illness.

Differential diagnosis



  • Atrial fibrillation (
    figure 2
    ):  demonstrates irregular R-R intervals, but no organized P waves are present (fibrillation waves may be present).
  • Sinus tachycardia (
    figure 3
    ):  demonstrates a rapid and regular rhythm, with P waves preceding each QRS complex.  Because all atrial conduction originates in the sinus node, all P waves have normal morphology, and the PR interval and P-P interval are constant.
  • Wandering atrial pacemaker:  is very similar to MAT (ie, â‰¥3 P-wave morphologies, irregular rhythm), but the atrial rate is normal (ie, 60-100/min).  It is usually seen in clinically stable patients without acute illness.
  • Sinus rhythm with frequent premature atrial contractions:  can demonstrate an irregular rhythm with multiple P-wave morphologies.  However, it usually shows only 2 P-wave morphologies: normal sinus P waves as the predominant P-wave morphology and a second P-wave morphology for the premature atrial beats that originate from a portion of the atria outside the sinoatrial node.

Management



The initial management of MAT focuses on treatment of the inciting acute disturbance.  For example, appropriate management of an acute COPD exacerbation (eg, bronchodilators, glucocorticoids, noninvasive positive pressure ventilation) typically results in the resolution of MAT.  Serum electrolyte levels should be monitored and abnormalities (eg, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia) appropriately corrected.



For MAT that persists despite appropriate management of the inciting disturbance, pharmacologic therapy with either a beta blocker (eg, metoprolol) or a nondihydropyridine calcium channel blocker (eg, verapamil) can help reduce atrial ectopy and slow conduction through the atrioventricular (AV) node to reduce heart rate.  Nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers are often preferred in patients with severe obstructive lung disease because beta blockers may worsen airway obstruction in the setting of active bronchospasm.



Antiarrhythmic medications and synchronized cardioversion are generally not useful in the management of MAT because they are usually ineffective in terminating the arrhythmia and restoring normal sinus rhythm.  Rarely, when MAT causes persistent symptoms or contributes to hemodynamic instability, radiofrequency ablation of the AV node with placement of a permanent pacemaker is an option for definitive management.

Complications



MAT that is allowed to persist for a prolonged period (eg, weeks or more) may cause tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy.  In contrast with atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter, MAT is not associated with a meaningful increase in thromboembolic risk.

Prognosis



The prognosis for MAT is mostly driven by the underlying disease process.  The arrhythmia usually resolves with successful treatment of the inciting acute disturbance.
